Breeding adult.description: Breeding adult Western Gulls are a darker shade of gray than Herring Gulls. Their bill is also more bulbous than the bill on Herring Gulls.

Nonbreeding adult.description: Nonbreeding adult Western Gulls have very little tan streaking on their neck unlike the heavily streaked nonbreeding adult Herring Gull.

Second winter.description: Second winter Western Gulls have darker gray feathers coming in on their back than second winter Herring Gulls. They also have a heavier and bulbous-shaped bill.

First winter.description: Bill size and shape may be the best way to separate first winter Western Gulls from younger Herring Gulls. The bill on Western is heavier with a bulbous shape, unlike the rather slim and straight bill on Herring Gulls.

Breeding adult.description: Ring-billed Gulls are smaller and more daintily built than Herring Gulls. Breeding birds have yellow legs and a black line around the bill, whereas breeding Herring Gulls have pink legs and a red mark on the lower bill.

Second winter.description: Size can help separate Ring-billed Gulls from Herring Gulls at all ages. Ring-billed Gulls are smaller with a daintier body than Herring Gulls.

First winter.description: First winter Ring-billed Gulls in general have less streaking on the underparts than first or second winter Herring Gulls.

Breeding adult.description: Breeding adult California Gulls have a dark eye unlike breeding Herring Gulls, which have a pale yellow eye. California Gulls also yellow legs not pink like Herring Gulls.

Nonbreeding adult.description: Nonbreeding adult California Gulls have dark eyes and yellow legs, whereas nonbreeding Herring Gulls have pale eyes and pink legs.

First winter.description: First winter California Gulls can be separated from first winter Herring Gulls by their smaller size and wings that stick our farther past the end of the tail.

Breeding adult.description: Breeding and nonbreeding adult Glaucous-winged Gulls have pale gray wingtips unlike adult Herring Gulls, which have black wingtips.

Second winter.description: First and second winter Glaucous-winged Gulls have pale tan wingtips, whereas first and second winter Herring Gulls have dark brown wingtips.

Adult (Iceland).description: Adult Iceland Gulls are highly variable, but they often have pale wingtips unlike the dark wingtips on adult Herring Gulls. Their bill is also smaller and slimmer than Herring Gulls.

Nonbreeding adult (Thayer's).description: Nonbreeding Iceland Gulls have paler gray wingtips than nonbreeding Herring Gulls. They also have a darker eye and a slimmer bill.

First winter (Thayer's).description: First winter Iceland Gulls look very similar to first winter Herring Gulls, but they have a slimmer bill and appear more round-headed that Herring Gulls.

Nonbreeding adult.description: Lesser Black-backed Gulls are darker gray above than Herring Gulls. They also have yellow (not pink) legs.

Juvenile.description: Juvenile Lesser Black-backed Gulls can be separated from juvenile or first winter Herring Gulls by their smudgy black eye patch.

Breeding adult.description: Great Black-backed Gulls are larger than Herring Gulls with much darker upperparts.

Second winter.description: Second winter Great Black-backed Gulls have paler heads than second winter or first winter Herring Gulls. They also have a heftier bulbous bill that is pink at the base and the tip.
